profileText: A Representative from New Hampshire; born in Wakefield, Carroll County, N.H., November 5, 1828; attended Gilmanton Academy, and was graduated from Dartmouth College, Hanover, N.H., in 1851; studied law; was admitted to the bar in 1855 and practiced in Wakefield and Dover, N.H.; solicitor of the county of Strafford 1862-1874; mayor of Dover in 1866 and 1867; member of the State senate 1871 and 1872; served in the State house of representatives in 1874; attorney of the United States for the district of Hampshire from April 1874 to February 1879; elected as a Republican to the Forty-sixth and Forty-seventh Congresses (March 4, 1879-March 3, 1883); resumed the practice of his profession; died in Dover, Strafford County, N.H., on October 31, 1898; interment in Pine Hill Cemetery.

researchRecord.name: In the "Testimony before the N.H. Commission on the State's Interest in the Concord Railroad Corporation," 1888, 12 pages.
researchRecord.description: The papers include typescript copy of testimony given by Frank Streeter before the New Hampshire Commission on the State's interest in the Concord Railroad. The testimony include questions posed by Hall.

researchRecord.name: In the "Extracts of Garrison Orders from Ft. Constitution," 1809-1814, 1 volume.
researchRecord.description: A volume labeled "property of Joshua G. Hall" and includes details of activities at reveille, daily rules of behavior, and orders for loading, aiming, and firing cannons and field artillery. There are no entries for the years 1810-1813.
